Caption: Fig. 1. Three categories of star glyph variations used in our three experiments. Data lines only (D): only the data lines encode the data; Data lines+Contour (D +C): data lines are connected at the endpoints to create a closed shape; Contour only (C): only the contour line is drawn. Additional variations are tickmarks (T ) (in b, e)), gridlines (G) (in c, f)), and ﬁll style (in g, h)).

Fig. 2. Experiment 1 Contour Variations: (from left to right) star glyph with where the correct answer was revealed to help learning. During the rays and no contour (D); common star glyph (D +C); only the contour line of the actual experiment the correct answer was no longer provided. star glyph (C). The three glyph variations were presented in an order randomized

Fig. 3. Experiment Setting: The participant was seated in front of a 24” Screen were visualization researchers and students who reported a strong back- with a resolution of 1920x1200. The only input device was a computer mouse. ground in data visualization with at least basic knowledge of reading

Fig. 4. Experiment Setting: For each trial glyphs were arranged in a 3×3 matrix. The stimulus is highlighted and positioned in the middle to assure an equal distance to the other glyphs. This setting is used in all three experiments.
Fig. 5. Experiment 1 Summary: The bar charts illustrate the percentage of correct answers and the standard deviation.

Fig. 6. Experiment 1 Results: The bar charts illustrate the percentage of selections and the standard deviation for each factor. In the high dimensional condition experts using variations D +C,C were lead to judge shape similarity rather than data similarity whereas the accuracy of novices was low for all three variations.
Fig. 9. Experiment 3 design space: We have chosen the star glyph only with data whiskers (D) and with an additional contour line (D +C) and applied tickmarks (T ) and gridlines (G) to these designs.

Fig. 8. Experiment 2 results: The bar charts illustrate the percentage of selections and the standard deviation for each factor. The left chart represents low dimensionality, the right one the high dimension condition. Even without training or explaining the visual encoding participants using variation D judged data similarity rather than shape similarity.

Fig. 10. Experiment 3 results of the percentage of selections and the stan- dard deviation for each factor. Design improvements (T, G) do not signiﬁcantly increase the accuracy of the two star glyph variations (D +C,C).
